page.title: 03LOCAL HISTORY 1
page.content: {Duddingston}got its name from a knight in Norman times called{Dodyn.}There is evidence of a possible crannog in the loch dated 8th century B.C. In the year 1120 the monks of Kelso built a church for the people of Easter and Wester Duddingston. In{Wester Duddingston}there was farming{(Northfield, Southfield and {Meadowfield)}and weaving of a coarse cloth called Duddingston Hardings. In {Easter Duddingston}there were salt pan workings at{Magdalene Bridge}from the 17th to the 20th century. From the 16th to the 18th century there was also coal mining in the area and many families were sold into slavery. The name{Joppa}may be derived from the old sea port in the Holy Land. {Portobello}is named after Puerto Bello in Panama, commemorating the defeat of the Spanish in 1739.
